pullRequest.body:
Adds a theorem saying the cardinality of a multiplicative subgroup of a field, cast to the field, is nonzero. As well as `sum_subgroup_units_zero_of_ne_bot` and other theorems about summing over multiplicative subgroups.

Co-authored-by: Pratyush Mishra <prat@upenn.edu>
Co-authored-by:  Buster <rcopley@gmail.com>


---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: Note: this is true for [infinite fields too](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/cast_subgroup_of_units_card_ne_zero.20for.20infinite.20fields/near/384013573), so I should generalize it.
Could you please reformat your `co-authored-by` line? It takes an email address (+ name) as argument. One co-author per line. See for example #3464.

> Could you please reformat your `co-authored-by` line? It takes an email address (+ name) as argument. One co-author per line. See for example #3464.

I don't see any co-authorship lines on that PR

Also, not aware if Buster (that's their Zulip handle) wants their email shared publicly.

Edit: although it's been pointed out to me that Zulip shows it anyway, so I guess there's no harm.
@ericrbg The `DecidableEq` instance is needed for the rest of the lemma statement, let me know what you want done about that.
I tried to do the golf, but was not getting it. Maybe actually `sum_pow_units` can be golfed too?
Given that everything apparently turned out to be true in NoZeroDivisor rings, I'd be interested to know if the preexisting lemmas in this file can be generalized along those lines.

This is as far as I got
```
/-- The sum of `x ^ i` as `x` ranges over a finite field of cardinality `q`
is equal to `0` if `i < q - 1`. -/
theorem sum_pow_lt_card_sub_one (i : ‚Ñï) (h : i < q - 1) : ‚àë x : K, x ^ i = 0 := by
  by_cases hi : i = 0
  ¬∑ simp only [hi, nsmul_one, sum_const, pow_zero, card_univ, cast_card_eq_zero]
  classical
    -- have hiq : ¬¨q - 1 ‚à£ i := by contrapose! h; exact Nat.le_of_dvd (Nat.pos_of_ne_zero hi) h
    let œÜ : KÀ£ ‚Ü™ K := ‚ü®fun x ‚Ü¶ x, Units.ext‚ü©
    have : univ.map œÜ = univ \ {0} := by
      ext x
      simp only [true_and_iff, Function.Embedding.coeFn_mk, mem_sdiff, Units.exists_iff_ne_zero,
        mem_univ, mem_map, exists_prop_of_true, mem_singleton]
    calc
      ‚àë x : K, x ^ i = ‚àë x in univ \ {(0 : K)}, x ^ i := by
        rw [‚Üê sum_sdiff ({0} : Finset K).subset_univ, sum_singleton,
          zero_pow (Nat.pos_of_ne_zero hi), add_zero]
      _ = ‚àë x : KÀ£, (x ^ i : K) := by simp [‚Üê this, univ.sum_map œÜ]
      _ = 0 := by 
        sorry
        -- convert sum_subgroup_pow_eq_zero (G := ‚ä§) (k := i) hi _
#align finite_field.sum_pow_lt_card_sub_one FiniteField.sum_pow_lt_card_sub_one
```

> Given that everything apparently turned out to be true in NoZeroDivisor rings, I'd be interested to know if the preexisting lemmas in this file can be generalized along those lines.

I think this can wait for a followup PR, but yes:)

ok also the refactoring can, lmao it took me forever

<details>
<summary>if you want to see</summary>

```lean
lemma Subgroup.prod_top {Œ± Œ≤ : Type*} [Group Œ±] [Fintype Œ±] [Fintype (‚ä§ : Subgroup Œ±)]
  [CommMonoid Œ≤] (f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤) : ‚àè x : (‚ä§ : Subgroup Œ±), f x = ‚àè x : Œ±, f x :=
  by simp [Finset.prod_set_coe]

lemma Subgroup.sum_top {Œ± Œ≤ : Type*} [Group Œ±] [Fintype Œ±] [Fintype (‚ä§ : Subgroup Œ±)]
  [AddCommMonoid Œ≤] (f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤) : ‚àë x : (‚ä§ : Subgroup Œ±), f x = ‚àë x : Œ±, f x :=
  by simp [Finset.sum_set_coe]

-- how to make these a `to_additive` pair?

lemma prod_units_nonunits {Œ± Œ≤ : Type*} [Monoid Œ±] [CommMonoid Œ≤] [Fintype Œ±] [Fintype Œ±À£]
  [Fintype <| nonunits Œ±] (f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤) :
    (‚àè x : Œ±À£, f x) * ‚àè x in (nonunits Œ±).toFinset, f x = ‚àè x : Œ±, f x := by
  rw [‚ÜêFinset.prod_set_coe, ‚ÜêFintype.prod_sum_elim]
  apply Fintype.prod_bijective (Sum.elim (¬∑ : Œ±À£ ‚Üí Œ±) (¬∑ : nonunits Œ± ‚Üí Œ±))
  swap; aesop
  refine ‚ü®?_, fun x ‚Ü¶ ?_‚ü©
  ¬∑ rintro (u | nu) (u | nu) h
    ¬∑ exact congr(Sum.inl $(Units.ext h))
    ¬∑ refine (nu.2 ?_).elim
      dsimp at h
      rw [‚Üêh]
      exact u.isUnit
    ¬∑ refine (nu.2 ?_).elim
      dsimp at h
      rw [h]
      exact u.isUnit
    ¬∑ refine congr(Sum.inr $(Subtype.ext h))
  ¬∑ by_cases h : IsUnit x
    ¬∑ exact ‚ü®.inl h.unit, rfl‚ü©
    ¬∑ exact ‚ü®.inr ‚ü®x, h‚ü©, rfl‚ü©

lemma sum_units_nonunits {Œ± Œ≤ : Type*} [Monoid Œ±] [AddCommMonoid Œ≤] [Fintype Œ±] [Fintype Œ±À£]
  [Fintype <| nonunits Œ±] (f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤) :
    (‚àë x : Œ±À£, f x) + ‚àë x in (nonunits Œ±).toFinset, f x = ‚àë x : Œ±, f x :=
prod_units_nonunits (Œ≤ := Multiplicative Œ≤) f

-- attribute [to_additive] prod_units_nonunits sum_units_nonunits
-- this is the "correct" additivization but not sure how to tell `to_additive` that

@[simp] lemma nonunits_eq_zero {G : Type*} [GroupWithZero G] : nonunits G = {0} :=
  Set.ext <| fun x ‚Ü¶ by simpa [nonunits] using (isUnit_iff_ne_zero (a := x)).not

/-- The sum of `x ^ i` as `x` ranges over a finite field of cardinality `q`
is equal to `0` if `i < q - 1`. -/
theorem sum_pow_lt_card_sub_one (i : ‚Ñï) (h : i < q - 1) : ‚àë x : K, x ^ i = 0 := by
  by_cases hi : i = 0
  ¬∑ simp only [hi, nsmul_one, sum_const, pow_zero, card_univ, cast_card_eq_zero]
  classical
  rw [‚ÜêFintype.card_units, ‚ÜêSubgroup.card_top] at h
  have key := sum_subgroup_pow_eq_zero (K := K) (G := ‚ä§) hi (by convert h)
  erw [Subgroup.sum_top ((¬∑ : KÀ£ ‚Üí K) ^ i : KÀ£ ‚Üí K)] at key
  rw [‚Üêsum_units_nonunits, ‚Üê key]
  simp [hi]

#align finite_field.sum_pow_lt_card_sub_one FiniteField.sum_pow_lt_card_sub_one
```

</details>

so I'll do this in a separate PR tidying up the file

bors d+
I'm confused by this statement; isn't the cardinality of _any_ subgroup non-zero because it contains 1?

Maybe you're confused by the casting to the field? While the cardinality of any subgroup is obviously a non-zero natural, it's not immediately obvious that this natural, when cast to the field, does not yield the zero of the field.

Or maybe you're interested in infinite fields as well? ~~Let me see if anything fails when I remove the finiteness from the field.~~ Actually the whole proof fails as it is, because it's about showing the characteristic divides the difference between the field and the units cardinality. I'm not sure if this holds for infinite fields, I don't know a proof either way.
Oh, I just totally missed the cast!


```suggestion
/-- If `e` is an equivalence of finite types, then `Multiset.map e` sends the universal finite set
to the universal finite set. -/
@[simp]
theorem _root_.Equiv.multiset_map_univ_eq_univ (e : Œ± ‚âÉ Œ≤) :
    map e univ.val = univ.val := by
```
Looks like there's actually a Finset version called `Finset.map_univ_equiv` so I'll name this analogously. LMK if you really want this name.

```suggestion
variable [Fintype Œ±] [DecidableEq Œ±] [Fintype Œ≤]
```

this is a weird docstring, I feel like it's never referred to as "universal finite set"; I'm not sure it's needed that you spell this out, to be honest
Ok, I'll just delete it

A few golfs, and actually this holds for a not-necessarily commutative ring with no zero divisors & nontrivial, and I don't see why it would hold in more generality than this.

`<|` is preferred in Lean4 to `$`, as far as I can see. 

```suggestion
theorem cast_subgroup_of_units_card_ne_zero {F : Type} [Ring F] [NoZeroDivisors F] [Nontrivial F]
    (G : Subgroup FÀ£) [Fintype G] : (Fintype.card G : F) ‚â† 0 := by
  let n := Fintype.card G
  intro nzero
  have ‚ü®p, char_p‚ü© := CharP.exists F
  have hd : p ‚à£ n := (CharP.cast_eq_zero_iff F p n).mp nzero
  cases CharP.char_is_prime_or_zero F p with
  | inr pzero =>
    exact (Fintype.card_pos).ne' <| Nat.eq_zero_of_zero_dvd <| pzero ‚ñ∏ hd
  | inl pprime =>
    have fact_pprime := Fact.mk pprime
    -- G has an element x of order p by Cauchy's theorem
    have ‚ü®x, hx‚ü© := exists_prime_orderOf_dvd_card p hd
    -- F has an element u (= ‚Üë‚Üëx) of order p
    let u := ((x : FÀ£) : F)
    have hu : orderOf u = p := by rwa [orderOf_units, orderOf_subgroup]
    -- u ^ p = 1 implies (u - 1) ^ p = 0 and hence u = 1 ...
    have h : u = 1 := by
      rw [‚Üê sub_left_inj, sub_self 1]
      apply pow_eq_zero (n := p)
      rw [sub_pow_char_of_commute, one_pow, ‚Üê hu, pow_orderOf_eq_one, sub_self]
      exact Commute.one_right u
    -- ... meaning x didn't have order p after all, contradiction
    apply pprime.one_lt.ne
    rw [‚Üê hu, h, orderOf_one]
```

I tried this, but `exists_pow_ne_one_of_isCyclic` is supposed to take a Type, whereas `sum_pow_lt_card_sub_one` is polymorphic over universes for the Field, and that seemed to cause issues.

It's sort of tragic that this is the case, I shouldn't have to deal with this for meat and potatoes theorems about fields.

Notice that `sum_subgroup_pow_eq_zero` specifies a type `F` for the field different from the polymorphic one that the rest of the lemmas in this section get. Should I move the lemma? Should I fix `exists_pow_ne_one_of_isCyclic` to be polymorphic? Should I fix `K` to be `Type`?
In fact the problems are weirder, ~~there is one K shadowing another.~~ maybe this syntax is just respecifying the explicitness?
I feel this is a question for the zulip
I think you should try to make everything universe polymorphic, if possible
Ok, I have just gone and made exists_pow_ne_one_of_isCyclic polymorphic, feel free to golf the other proof if you'd like.

```lean
lemma Subgroup.prod_top {Œ± Œ≤ : Type*} [Group Œ±] [Fintype Œ±] [Fintype (‚ä§ : Subgroup Œ±)]

lemma prod_units_nonunits {Œ± Œ≤ : Type*} [Monoid Œ±] [CommMonoid Œ≤] [Fintype Œ±] [Fintype Œ±À£]
  [Fintype <| nonunits Œ±] (f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤) :

  rw [‚ÜêFinset.prod_set_coe, ‚ÜêFintype.prod_sum_elim]

  swap; aesop
  refine ‚ü®?_, fun x ‚Ü¶ ?_‚ü©
  ¬∑ rintro (u | nu) (u | nu) h
    ¬∑ exact congr(Sum.inl $(Units.ext h))
    ¬∑ refine (nu.2 ?_).elim
      dsimp at h
      rw [‚Üêh]
      exact u.isUnit
    ¬∑ refine (nu.2 ?_).elim
      dsimp at h
      rw [h]
      exact u.isUnit
    ¬∑ refine congr(Sum.inr $(Subtype.ext h))
  ¬∑ by_cases h : IsUnit x

    ¬∑ exact ‚ü®.inr ‚ü®x, h‚ü©, rfl‚ü©

lemma sum_units_nonunits {Œ± Œ≤ : Type*} [Monoid Œ±] [AddCommMonoid Œ≤] [Fintype Œ±] [Fintype Œ±À£]
  [Fintype <| nonunits Œ±] (f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤) :
    (‚àë x : Œ±À£, f x) + ‚àë x in (nonunits Œ±).toFinset, f x = ‚àë x : Œ±, f x :=
prod_units_nonunits (Œ≤ := Multiplicative Œ≤) f

@[simp] lemma nonunits_eq_zero {G : Type*} [GroupWithZero G] : nonunits G = {0} :=
  Set.ext <| fun x ‚Ü¶ by simpa [nonunits] using (isUnit_iff_ne_zero (a := x)).not

/-- The sum of `x ^ i` as `x` ranges over a finite field of cardinality `q`
is equal to `0` if `i < q - 1`. -/
theorem sum_pow_lt_card_sub_one (i : ‚Ñï) (h : i < q - 1) : ‚àë x : K, x ^ i = 0 := by
  by_cases hi : i = 0
  ¬∑ simp only [hi, nsmul_one, sum_const, pow_zero, card_univ, cast_card_eq_zero]
  classical
  rw [‚ÜêFintype.card_units, ‚ÜêSubgroup.card_top] at h
  have key := sum_subgroup_pow_eq_zero (K := K) (G := ‚ä§) hi (by convert h)
  erw [Subgroup.sum_top ((¬∑ : KÀ£ ‚Üí K) ^ i : KÀ£ ‚Üí K)] at key
  rw [‚Üêsum_units_nonunits, ‚Üê key]
  simp [hi]

#align finite_field.sum_pow_lt_card_sub_one FiniteField.sum_pow_lt_card_sub_one
```
